column46: OTHER INFO
Hotspots

column3: Disease type, or whether treated / untreated.
column5: Basic reproduction number, average estimate. Normally mean of extreme estimates.
column6: Adult case fatality rate (CFR): % of those who contract the disease who die from it. Adults or, if adult data not available, all people.
column7: Biosafety containment / hazard level from 1 to 4. Higher number is more hazardous, more precautions required.
column8: Max. survival time on surfaces, days
column9: Max. survival in ideal conditions outside host or vector (ie. blood, faeces), days
column10: Adult CFR grouped into seven categories: Virtually zero (CFR < 0.1%), very low (0.1% <  1%), low (1% < 10%), moderate (10% < 50%), high (50% < 80%), very high (80% < 100%) and virtually certain (~100%).
column11: Child case fatality rate (CFR), %. Age cutoff varies (where GHDX is source: always 14 and under)
column13: Hits on google.co.uk, News, date range 2000-2018, data retreived 3/1/2018
column14: Inflammation rating 1: MOST NEWS ATTENTION. News hits as % general hits
column15: Inflammation rating 2: MOST YUCKY. Google news hits per annual death
column16: Inflammation rating 3: MOST FEAR INDUCING. Google hits per annual death
column17: Press vs Contagiousness: MOST IGNORED. Contagiousness / news hits (higher = most ignored)
column19: Notoriety to fatalities rate ratio. Google hits / world case fatality rate
column20: Primary mode of transmission: air droplets, bites, body fluids, fecal-oral, food and water, other
column21: Minimum infectious dose - minimum pathogen particles required to infect someone (or an animal, where noted)
column22: Minimum infectious dose grouped - minimum pathogen particles required to infect someone (or an animal, where noted). Grouped into log10 categories 1, 10, 100 etc.
column23: Human or animal. Was min. infectious dose ascertained in human or animal studies?
column24: Incubation period, average number of days
column25: Incubation period, range in days (from X to Y days), plus notes
column26: New cases of disease per year for latest available year, global, millions, rounded
column27: New cases of disease per year for latest available year, global, not rounded
column28: New cases of disease per year for latest available year, United States
column29: New cases of disease per year for latest available year, Europe
column30: New cases of disease per year for latest available year, Africa
column31: Number of current cases, global, rounded, in millions
column32: Number of current cases, global, not rounded
column33: Disability-adjusted life years: Years per year lived with disease or lost to early mortality. Global, millions, rounded.
column34: Disability-adjusted life years: Years per year lived with disease or lost to early mortality. Global, not rounded.
column35: Disability-adjusted life years: Years per year lived with disease or lost to early mortality. United States
column36: Disability-adjusted life years: Years per year lived with disease or lost to early mortality. Europe
column37: Disability-adjusted life years: Years per year lived with disease or lost to early mortality. Africa
column38: Deaths per year: average or latest year. Global, rounded (not in millions)
column39: Deaths per year: average or latest year. Global, not rounded.
column40: Deaths per year: average or latest year. United States.
column41: Deaths per year: average or latest year. Europe.
column42: Deaths per year: average or latest year. Africa.
column43: Peak fatalities: highest deaths in worst historical year of outbreak. Global except where noted
column45: Most vulnerable populations. Who gets infected the most?
column46: Geographical hotspots of disease: nations, areas
column48: How effective is the treatment listed?
column49: Any resistance of pathogen to treatment noted?

Asia and Africa. India has the highest rate of human rabies in the world, primarily because of stray dogs,[83] whose number has greatly increased since a 2001 law forbade the killing of dogs.[84] Effective control and treatment of rabies in India is also hindered by a form of mass hysteria known as puppy pregnancy syndrome (PPS). Dog bite victims with PPS (both male and female) become convinced that puppies are growing inside them, and often seek help from faith healers rather than from conventional medical services.[85] An estimated 20,000 people die every year from rabies in India â more than a third of the global toll.[84]
column48: Vaccine given before onset of symptoms is 100% effective

column46: Asia and Africa. India has the highest rate of human rabies in the world, primarily because of stray dogs,[83] whose number has greatly increased since a 2001 law forbade the killing of dogs.[84] Effective control and treatment of rabies in India is also hindered by a form of mass hysteria known as puppy pregnancy syndrome (PPS). Dog bite victims with PPS (both male and female) become convinced that puppies are growing inside them, and often seek help from faith healers rather than from conventional medical services.[85] An estimated 20,000 people die every year from rabies in India â more than a third of the global toll.[84]
